nodes.text: The inverse-S probability weighting observed in behavioural experiments can be explained mechanistically by differences between the observer's (DO) and decision maker's (DM) probabilistic models, rather than by a cognitive bias of the DM

Probability weighting is the empirical pattern that decision weight CDF Fw plotted against observer probability CDF Fp generically produces an inverse-S curve: Fw > Fp for low cumulative probabilities and Fw < Fp for high ones

A DM assuming a larger scale (greater uncertainty) than the DO for the same unimodal distribution produces decision weights w(x) that exceed probabilities p(x) for low-probability events and are lower for high-probability events, yielding an inverse-S mapping of CDFs

Relative estimation errors in finite-time frequency estimates are larger for rarer events, so a cautious DM who adjusts estimated densities by adding an uncertainty correction will systematically inflate rare-event weights and deflate common-event weights after normalization
Tversky and Kahneman's phenomenological mapping function ËœF_TK(Fp; gamma) fits inverse-S data but lacks mechanistic motivation and can introduce artefactual shifts in intersection with diagonal

Analytic Gaussian example: if DO uses N(mu, sigma^2) and DM uses N(mu, (alpha sigma)^2) with alpha>1, then w as function of p is a power law in p with exponent 1/alpha^2 < 1, producing w>p for small p and w
Generalisation: differing location and/or shape parameters between DO and DM (including t-distributions) also reproduce the inverse-S shape, so the effect does not depend on Gaussianity

Formal correction model: DM forms estimated density p_hat(x)=n(x)/(T delta x) and uncertainty epsilon[p_hat] ~ sqrt(p_hat/(T delta x)); DM constructs w(x) proportional to p_hat(x)+epsilon[p_hat(x)] and normalizes
Phenomenological two-parameter mappings (e.g., Lattimore et al.) can fit data but are not physically grounded in observation-derived uncertainty mechanisms
Analytic and numerical illustrations show that larger DM assumed scale and/or added uncertainty correction produce inverse-S CDF mappings visually similar to experimental data

Simulations: DMs estimating densities by counting in finite series (T observations, bin width delta x) and applying the conservative addition of one standard error produce inverse-S mappings for Gaussian and fat-tailed t-distributed data; effect stronger for fat tails

Fits to experimental data (Tversky and Kahneman 1992; Tversky and Fox 1995): Gaussian and t-models with fitted location and scale/shape parameters match empirical inverse-S curves as well as phenomenological functions, supporting the mechanistic explanation

Conclusion: Observed probability weighting can be interpreted as rational, cautious DM behaviour given limited time-series information and model uncertainty, and not necessarily as DM cognitive bias; inverse-S is neutral about which model is correct

Assumption: DO and DM interpret 'probability' differently (ensemble vs time-frequency vs degree-of-belief) and DMs often act with incentives tied to time evolution (ergodicity considerations), motivating extra caution

Limitation: The mechanistic model depends on DM using frequency estimates from finite time series and applying a conservative uncertainty correction; alternative psychological mechanisms are not excluded and empirical noise limits identifiability between models
